On #HumanRightsDay my support goes out to those working to defend #humanrights on a national & local scale. I‚Äôm proud to help lead the Int‚Äôl #ReligiousFreedom & #VictimsofCommunism caucuses to stand up for human rights across the globe. #StandUp4HumanRights

Congress‚Äô work will not end with this vote.Pharma‚Äôs been left in charge for too long leading to jaw-dropping prices with no connection to real research costs.I will continue to advocate to protect family pocketbooks & hold Big Pharma accountable for abuse of our healthcare system

I‚Äôm also cosponsoring amendments to end the ban on Medicare drug price negotiation entirely and to make sure people paying out-of-pocket are also eligible to get the discounted prices from this bill. The uninsured shouldn‚Äôt be left out. 5

This bill is a step in the right direction, but it‚Äôs not perfect. That‚Äôs why I‚Äôve offered an amendment to guarantee price negotiation on ALL life-sustaining Rx. The bill requires negotiation for as few as 25 drugs to start, which means some life-sustaining meds could be missed. 4

This could get the total cost of a breast cancer drug like Ibrance down from $69,000 to $23,900 annually. Another example: diabetes patients could spend 3.5x less on insulin under the bill than before. Some common types of insulin may drop to as low as $400/year. 3

For the first time, Medicare will negotiate on prices to get a better deal for patients for some drugs. People with private health insurance will benefit too, because the negotiated discounts will also apply to drugs on the private market. 2

This week we‚Äôll vote on H.R. 3, the Lower Drug Costs Now Act, to help patients afford their Rx. Savings in the bill will be used to cap out-of-pocket drug spending for Medicare patients at $2K/year and create new dental, hearing, and vision benefits under Medicare. 1
